content: Ref: UCMJ, Article 92. Failure to Obey Order or Regulation. Obviously, active duty personnel are responsible to follow guidelines identified below. Currently, members of the Army Awards Branch are misinterpreting, ignoring, or refuse to follow guidelines pertaining to WWII era veterans. Specifically AR 600-45, dated 22 September 1943, and 3 May 1944. There is no doubt severe frostbite was a wound, and warrants the Purple Heart medal regardless of incurring said wound during "action against an enemy of the United States" (Combat) " or as a direct result of an act of such enemy" (In captivity). It has been my experience members of aforementioned office refuse to recognize WWII veterans that experienced frostbite caused by the enemy forced marches while in captivity in Europe during the winter of 1944/1945. I base the above statements on previous correspondence with the Army, the legal opinion from Colonel Theodore Jarvi, USAFR, Retired, former JAG Officer, and action by AF Board for Correction of Military Records contrary to the Army. Most recent response after the initial request, and appeal (both denying the Purple Heart), suggests the next of kin of a veteran that participated in the Battle of the Bulge to "seek relief in a court of appropriate jurisdiction." My purpose is to question the avenue involving the UCMJ. Is it feasible? Robert

content: Frostbite is an injury, not a wound. Unless the enemy held your foot in ice water, your inability to properly cloth yourself does not qualify for a Purple Heart. Soldiers at Valley Forge did not get the PH. Korean Vets did not get the PH for cold exposure. Heat exhaustion, malaria, scurvy, and many other negative health effects of service does not qualify for the PH.

content: I am more thankful for your service than you'll ever fully realize, sir. You truly are all that makes America great! But I must agree with the consensus here. It is my opinion, and only just, that a PH should be awarded only as a DIRECT result of enemy action. Re-word, twist and interpret the terms of the award all you will, but the PH is intended to depict a wound suffered in action by an enemy. While elements are an enemy unto themselves, they do not warrant the PH. Once again, I am more appreciative of your service than you'll ever know, sir. The whole world is! Please do not take offense at my words. None of us served for pretty ribbons or trinkets-named-medals. You helped save the world from a regime bent on detoxifying the world of those that looked and believed different than them; where Utopia existed only on the cornerstone of hate and bigotry in the name of a false god. You have earned more than a medal. You have earned respect. Leave it at that, and know that you personally helped change a planet. No medal can replace that, sir. Let it go and focus on what you do today. Very respectfully, and with deep admiration, Richard US Army Infantry, 1989-1993 (active) It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.

content: quote: I wonder what the percentages are of all servicemen during the Korean war are that have frostbite? Interesting topic!! According to Army Awards Branch on 23 August 1951, Army policy changed and award of the Purple Heart was no longer authorized for frostbite injuries. Such injuries incurred thereafter were considered to be accidental in nature and not the direct result of enemy action. Conclusion: It is concluded that the Purple Heart was authorized for severe cases of frostbite betwwen 13 November 1943 and 21 August 1951. Robert
